4. She was confident and assertive, using her tongue as a powerful tool to get what she wanted. She said, "A woman has nothing but her tongue, and while I live I will use mine."
5. She was also able to use humor and wit to make her points. For example, she told Roxie to take two white beans out of one hull and place them on the top of the garden fence, and then look at them across the garden, and if she could tell which one was the largest, she could see what difference there was in the way old Perkins hated style and she hated his poor kin.
6. She was able to use her conversational style to manipulate others. For example, she was able to make Roxie feel guilty for questioning her treatment of Jim, saying "I am good to Jim, poor soul, he knows it."
7. She was also able to use her conversational style to express her emotions and opinions. For example, she expressed her frustration and anger towards old Perkins and his poor kin, saying "What if he did make a thousand dollars last week, when he wants to stick his poor kin 'round me, like stumps in a flower garden."

In relation to her social interactions in Chicago, Aunt Patsy was described as a prominent figure in upper-tendom, understood by the grandest ladies in the city. She was able to move freely in high society, and her opinions and advice were sought after by others.

In relation to her remarks to Mrs. Daymon, Aunt Patsy was described as being direct and assertive, using her tongue to express her opinions and feelings. She was able to use humor and wit to make her points, and she was confident and assertive in her interactions with others.
